channel.title: Data visualization on Visual Analytics
channel.description: Recent content in Data visualization on Visual Analytics

item.title: Python
item.description: Contents Announcements Final Projects. Due next class 12/9. Course Evaluations Tweet of the day Slides/Lab Announcements Final Projects. Due next class 12/9. Your final project will have three deliverables due on Canvas: Your app (e.g., as a zip file, github, RStudio.Cloud link) Your presentation slides (e.g., pptx or zip file with xaringan)If you submit xaringan, I highly recommend submitting a .pdf that you can get by viewing your xaringan in full screen, then right click > ‚Äúprint‚Äù and then save as pdf.

item.title: Quiz 4
item.description:
Quiz 4 can be taken starting on November 25: Canvas link to Quiz 4 You will have one week to complete the quiz (that is, the quiz must be completed by 5:59pm on December 2nd, 2019).This is not by midnight, but before the next class.
This quiz will consist of 10 multiple choice questions. You will have 15 minutes to complete the quiz. You may only take the quiz once.

item.title: Shiny in Production
item.description: Contents Annoucements Tweet of the Day Materials 1. Shiny in Production Workshop 2. Joe Cheng‚Äôs Shiny in Production 3. Hands-on Annoucements Final Projects. Optional 20 min project check-ins this Sat, Dec 1 (12-4pm) and Mon, Dec 3 (12-1pm).For each group, please select no more than 1 time. If some group members can‚Äôt make it physically, consider bringing in calling or using Google Hangouts - students are responsible for setting it up!

item.title: Shiny in Production
item.description: Required Chapter 1, Chapter 3, Chapter 4 and Chapter 5 in Colin Fay, Vincent Guyader, Cervan Girard, S√©bastien Rochette, Building Big Shiny Apps - A Workflow.This book is under development. Recommended Shiny In Production Workshop Docker and `plumber‚Äô Profiling a Shiny App Persistent storage in Shiny Apps / RStudio blog post on persistent storage Plot caching

item.title: Interactions & Frameworks
item.description: Contents Announcements Tweet(s) of the day: Hands-on Class Creating PowerPoint using R Hands-on Work Helpful Links 1. Brusing & interaction: 2. shinydashboard 3. Helper functions: dragulaR, shinyWidgets / shiny demo, and waiter 4. Optional slides Announcements Quiz 3 grades. Problem Set 4 posted. We‚Äôll spend the last half of class starting this. DataCamp 4 due 11:59pm on Tuesday, Nov 26. Tweet(s) of the day: üéÖ Major announcement for #rstats shiny addictsüéÖ:

item.title: Interactivity and Brushing
item.description: Required Chapters 6: Workflow, Chapters 7: User feedback, Chapters 8: Uploads and downloads and Chapters 9: Dynamic UI in Hadley Wickham Mastering Shiny

item.description: Required Chapters 6: Workflow, Chapters 7: User feedback, Chapters 8: Uploads and downloads and Chapters 9: Dynamic UI in Hadley Wickham Mastering Shiny Chapter 7: Interactions in Riccardo Mazza, Introduction to Information Visualization Recommended Interactive Dynamics for Visual Analysis by Jeff Heer and Ben Shneiderman

item.description:
Quiz 3 can be taken starting on November 12th: Canvas link to Quiz 3 You will have one week to complete the quiz (that is, the quiz must be completed by 5:59pm on November 18, 2019).This is not by midnight, but before the next class.
This quiz will consist of 10 multiple choice questions. You will have 15 minutes to complete the quiz. You may only take the quiz once.

item.title: Reactive Programming
item.description: Contents Announcements Tweet(s) of the day: Hands-on Class Announcements Problem Set 3 due next by 11:59pm next Monday (11/18) Quiz 3 has been assigned and will be available at midnight. It is due next before class 5:59pm next Monday (11/18). DataCamp 4 due date has been pushed back to Tuesday (11/26). You should have your groups and your dataset for your Final Project.

item.title: Final project
Datacamp Course 4
item.description: DataCamp Course: Building Web Applications in R with Shiny: Case Studies by Dean Attali Here is the link to the assigned course. For this DataCamp course, you‚Äôll learn more about shiny using hands on case studies. The instructor for this course is a shiny expert who‚Äôs shinyjs package helps blend JavaScript code snippets within Shiny. He also has a great advanced shiny blog post that provides a lot of great tips for more customized functionality.

item.title: Intro to Shiny
item.description: Contents Tweet of the day Announcements Slides: Lab: Sample Shiny Apps Tweet of the day New blog post: ‚ÄúAdvice to aspiring data scientists: start a blog‚Äù https://t.co/yMDHqviiBN #rstats pic.twitter.com/9AdPUdbjtE ‚Äî David Robinson (@drob) November 14, 2017 David authored ‚ÄúTidy Text Mining‚Äù, which you‚Äôll use in problem set 3. David also occasionally does #tidytuesday live coding sessions. Extremely helpful to watch him in action.

item.title: Intro to Shiny
item.description: Required Chapters 2: Your First Shiny App, Chapters 3: Basic UI, and Chapters 4: Basic Reactivity in Hadley Wickham Mastering Shiny

Agenda and layout These groups were randomly assigned. Please plan to present in 8 minutes with 1-2 min for questions. Time Item 6:00 PM Intro 6:20 PM Group X 6:30 PM Group X 6:40 PM Group X 6:50 PM Group X 7:00 PM Group X 7:10 PM Group X 7:20 PM Group X 7:30 PM 10 min Break 7:40 PM Group X 7:50 PM Group X 8:00 PM Group X 8:10 PM Group X 8:20 PM Group X 8:30 PM Group X

item.title: Networks and Trees
item.description: Required Chapter 5: Networks and Hiearchies in Riccardo Mazza, Introduction to Information Visualization Katya Ognyanova, ‚ÄúStatic and dynamic network visualization with R‚Äù Recommended Chapters 2-9 in John Coene, Twinetbook

item.title: Datacamp Course 3
item.description: DataCamp Course: (Modified for this assignment) DataCamp no longer offers their ‚ÄúIntro to Shiny‚Äù. Instead, you have two options: Watch a 2.5 hour introduction to Shiny training video. Go through and read RStudio‚Äôs Shiny Introduction Article Series Since I can‚Äôt verify your completion, to complete this assignment you must submit on Canvas this statement: ‚ÄúOn my honor, I have completed option X for DataCamp course 3.‚Äù (where you state whether you did #1 or #2 in place of X).

item.title: Multidimensional & Dimensionality Reduction
item.description: Contents Announcements Tweet of the day Slides: Lab: Text and t-SNE Announcements Quiz 2 will be available tomorrow morning. You have until 5:59pm, Monday October 21 to complete. Canvas link to Quiz 2 Tomorrow, RStudio Engineer Davis Vaughn (SpeakerDeck) will be presenting for the Charlotte RMeetup Group tomorrow from 12-1pm at CenterCity 1102. Remember, if you attend (must attend the full hour), per the Extra Credit Policy, you will receive 1% extra credit for attending.

item.title: Multidimensional & Dimensionality Reduction
item.description:
Required Chapter 12: Visualizing associations in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/.
Chapter 4: Multivariate Analysis in Riccardo Mazza, Introduction to Information Visualization Recommended Kieran Healy, ‚ÄúTwo y-axes‚Äù Tyler Bradley, ‚ÄúPCA in a tidy(verse) framework‚Äù David Schoch, ‚ÄúDimensionality Reduction Methods using FIFA 18 Player Data‚Äù

item.title: Networks & Trees
item.description: Contents Announcements Tweet of the day Slides: Links: Lab: Networks & Trees Announcements Quiz 2 Problem Set 2 Design Contest next week and DataCamp 3 due in two weeks (Nov 5.) Using the #wesanderson üé®üì¶ of course!

item.title: Quiz 2
item.description: Quiz 2 can be taken starting on October 15th: Canvas link to Quiz 2 You will have one week to complete the quiz (that is, the quiz must be completed by 5:59pm on October 21, 2019). Note this is not by midnight, but before the next class. This quiz will consist of 10 multiple choice questions. You will have 20 minutes to complete the quiz. You may only take the quiz once.

item.title: Design contest: TidyTuesdays
item.description: For this contest, you will find someone else‚Äôs submitted #TidyTuesday submission, critique it, then offer suggestions on ways to improve and enhance their work. Goals: Become familar with TidyTuesday and the R Online Learning Community Learn through someone else‚Äôs submission on novel visualization techniques, how to provide code in open source (e.g., how people post code on GitHub, etc.), and how to provide constructive design feedback on existing designs.

item.title: Extra Credit 1
item.description: Task 0: Getting started For this extra credit (worth 2% on your final grade), you‚Äôll learn blogdown, an R package that enables building websites through Hugo, a web framework. Like shiny, blogdown enable you to use a more complex framework (i.e., Hugo) but through R functions and syntax that you‚Äôve been learning about all semester. I recommend running this exercise on your personal laptop, mainly so you‚Äôll have this blog site already saved on your own personal computer.

item.title: Statistical Models
item.description: Required Chapter 6: Work with Models in Healy. Chapter 22: Model introduction and Chapter 23: Model basics in Wickham/Grolemund. Recommended Chapter 6: Basic Regression from ‚ÄúModernDive: An Introduction to Statistical and Data Sciences via R‚Äù by Chester Ismay and Albert Y. Kim.This is an outstanding new book ‚Äì with a free online version ‚Äì that will be a big complement to the tidyverse in the future.

item.title: Distributions & Uncertainty
item.description:
Required Chapter 7: Histograms and density plots, Chapter 8: Empirical cumulative distribution functions, Chapter 9: Visualizing many distributions at once and Chapter 16: Visualizing uncertainty in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/.
Multiple Views Blog: Uncertainty Visualizations Explained by Jessica Hullman and Matthew Kay Recommended Why It‚Äôs So Hard for Us to Visualize Uncertainty

item.title: Distributions & Uncertainty
item.description: Contents Annoucements Tweet of the Day: Slides: Lab 5: Links: Annoucements DataCamp 2 is due by 11:59pm Tuesday, Sept 24th. Reminder that Problem Set 2 is due by 11:59pm Monday, Oct 7th (during Fall Break). Charlotte R Meetup Group. Possibly present on Tuesday, 12-1pm in 12/17 meeting. See Slack channel post. Tweet of the Day: My ??? talk is now in video form: A biased tour of the uncertainty visualization zoo.

item.title: Problem set 2
item.description: Task 0: Getting started Create a new RStudio project somewhere on your computer.⊕Remember, in RStudio, ‚ÄúFile > New Project ..‚Äù) Open that new folder in Windows Explorer or macOS Finder (however you navigate around the files on your computer), and create a subfolder there named data. Download the file below and place it in your new data/ folder.⊕You‚Äôll probably need to right click on each and choose ‚ÄúSave link as‚Ä¶‚Äù.

item.title: Time & Space
item.description: Contents Announcements Tweet of the day Lab 4: Ch. 5 and Ch. 7 of Healy Slides Links: For deeper dives into time/spatial data Announcements Problem Set 1 is due tonight by 11:59pm Monday, Sept 16th. 50% penalty if turned in within 24 hours of deadline. 0% credit if turned in 24+ hours of deadline. Quiz 1 has closed. We will review answers in class. DataCamp 2 is due by 11:59pm Tuesday, Sept 24th.

item.title: Time & Space
item.description:
Required Chapter 7: Maps in Kieran Healy, Data VisualizationKieran Healy, Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018), http://socviz.co/.
Chapter 13: Visualizing time series, Chapter 14: Visualizing trends and Chapter 15: Visualizing geospatial trends in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/.
Chapter 16: Dates and times in Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham, R for Data ScienceHadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund, R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2017), http://r4ds.

item.title: Datacamp Course 2
item.description: DataCamp Course: Exploratory Data Analysis in R by David Robinson Here is the link to the assigned course. For this DataCamp course, you‚Äôll learn about doing exploratory data analysis, focusing on ggplot2 and the related tidyverse packages (e.g., dplyr, broom).

item.title: Quiz 1
item.description: Quiz 1 can be taken starting on September 10th. You will have one week to complete the quiz (that is, the quiz must be completed by 5:59pm on September 16, 2019). Note this is not by midnight, but before the next class. This quiz will consist of 10 multiple choice questions. You will have 15 minutes to complete the quiz. You may only take the quiz once. Grades will not be available until the quiz closes.

item.title: Visual Representations II
item.description: Contents Tweet of the Day Announcements Slides Lab 3: Make a plot (ggplot2) Helpful Links Tweet of the Day üåü guide to visual encoding types from @tamaramunzner's "Visualization & Journalism" https://t.co/A2x96QYNoL #dataviz #infovis pic.twitter.com/2FIyXeWk4h — Mara Averick (@dataandme) October 17, 2018 Tamara Munzner is one of the most influential data visualization researchers. Her textbook ‚ÄúVisualization Analysis and Design‚Äù is one of the most popular data viz books and some of her former students are now leaders in data viz (e.

item.title: Visual Representations II
item.description:
Required Chapter 3: Make a Plot and Chapter 4: Show the right numbers in Kieran Healy, Data VisualizationKieran Healy, Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018), http://socviz.co/.
Chapter 5: Directory of Visualization and Chapter 6: Visualizing Amounts in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E. Wilke, Fundamentals of Data Visualization (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2018), https://serialmentor.com/dataviz/.
A Layered Grammar of Graphics by Hadley Wickham

item.title: Problem set 1
item.description: To complete this task, you MUST submit your final folder (compressed as a zip file) through here to Canvas by 11:59pm on September 16, 2019. Each person needs to submit their own folder! So if you work in pairs, both individuals have to submit a folder. Task 0 Either use RStudio.CloudIf you need help, see RStudio.Cloud‚Äôs primer or Primers like R Programming Basics or Working with Data. or make sure you install R and RStudio and tidyverse first.

item.title: Visual Representations I
item.description: Contents Tweet of the day Announcements Slides Tweet of the day Visual encoding is itself a data transformation, often applied after a chain of other transformations. This is ‚Äúfirst week of class‚Äù, table stakes stuff. Sad if true that we don‚Äôt internalize this! ‚Äî Jeffrey Heer (@jeffrey_heer) August 11, 2018 Enrico Bertini is a data visualization researcher at NYU who co-hosts (with Moritz Stefaner) the podcast ‚ÄúData Stories‚Äù, which I highly recommend.

item.title: Visual Representations I
item.description:
Required Chapter 3: Data visualization and Chapter 5: Data transformation in Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham, R for Data ScienceHadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund, R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data (Sebastopol, California: O‚ÄôReilly Media, 2017), http://r4ds.had.co.nz/.
Chapter 2: Aesthetic mapping, Chapter 3: Coordinate systems and axes, Chapter 4: Color scales, and Chapter 19: Common pitfalls of color use in Claus Wilke, Fundamentals of Data VisualizationClaus E.

item.title: Datacamp Course 1
item.description:
DataCamp Course: Introduction to the Tidyverse by David Robinson Here is the link to the assigned course. For this DataCamp course, you‚Äôll learn about using tidyverse package from David Robinson, Chief Data Scientist for DataCamp.David is a prolific data scientist and blogger, whose blog ‚ÄúVariance Explained‚Äù is one of the most popular data science blogs. He has a great blog post discussing the background of this course.
This course has four chapters:

item.title: Intro to Visual Analytics
item.description: Required There are no required readings for the first class.

item.title: Introduction to Visual Analytics
item.description: Contents Tweet of the day: Slides & Lab Tweet of the day: Any time I have been struggling to learn a new tool/technology/software ‚Ä¶ I go back to this short clip I cut out of ???'s 2014 ??? tutorial on Dplyr to motivate myself to keep pushing through ‚Ä¶ learning new tools is hard for everyone at the beginning! pic.twitter.com/RevpkSJqWc ‚Äî Aliakbar Akbaritabar (Ali) (@Akbaritabar) July 25, 2018 Hadley Wickham is the R guru amongst gurus.

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle, inverse Defining Uncertanity and Risk Knightian Uncertainty, a la Donald Rumsfeld Gigerenzer Separates the use of heuristics, or rule-of-thumbs class: middle, center, inverse Bayesian theory class: middle, center, inverse Safari example Overview Set-up: We‚Äôre on safari in South Africa and we want to see the lions. Problem: We‚Äôre uncertain to the lions‚Äô location. Application: How can we design a visualization tool to aid our driver to help find the lions?

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle Welcome

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle Welcome

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle, inverse The Truth Continuum (Chapter 3) ‚ÄúAny visualization is a model.‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe more adequately a model fits whatever it stands for without being needlessly complex, and the easier it is for its intended audience to interpret it correctly, the better it will be.‚Äù class: center, middle class: center, middle class: center, middle class: center class: center, middle class: center, middle ‚Äì ‚ÄúGood visualizations shouldn‚Äôt oversimplify information.

item.title: DSBA 5122: Visual Analytics
item.description: class: center, middle Welcome Introduce yourself Name What‚Äôs your academic and professional background? Programming & visualization experience (e.g., tools like R, Tableau, Spotfire, etc.) What are you interested in learning more about with data visualizations? To do by next class: Send me an introduction email rwesslen@uncc.edu answering these questions. It‚Äôs up to you on length. This is my chance to learn about your background.

item.title: Python
item.description: Required No required reading. Enjoy!

item.title: Time
item.description: Required Chapter 8 in Alberto Cairo, The Truthful ArtAlberto Cairo, The Truthful Art: Data, Charts, and Maps for Communication (Berkeley, California: New Riders, 2016). The Nuclear Threat‚ÄîThe Shadow Peace, part 1 11 Ways to Visualize Changes Over Time ‚Äì A Guide A bunch of (really) short blog posts: Streamgraphs: Economic trade flows with R A century of ocean shipping animated What is seasonal adjustment and why is it used?

item.title: Assignments
item.description: Attendance & Participation You are expected to attend class and actively participate (e.g., ask questions, provide your perspective). You are permitted to miss to have two (2) unexcused absences. Excused absences must be approved before the class and can only be approved for medical issues (with a doctor‚Äôs note) or work-travel related. Attendance will be taken during break on a written sheet of paper. Each unexcused absences after your first two unexcused absences will decrease your Attendance grade by 10%.

item.title: Final projects
item.description: Contents Helpful links For their final projects, students will develop their own Shiny app to develop an interactive visualization on an interesting data-intensive problem. Helpful links Mike Kearney‚Äôs list of 3,000+ Shiny Apps shared on TwitterThis site is a great place to start for getting motivation. Find someone else‚Äôs app. Look at their code. Get ideas of what can improve their visualization. Learn new ways to present data.

item.title: Installing R, RStudio, and tidyverse
item.description: You will do all of your visualization work in this class with the open source (and free!) programming language R. You will use RStudio as the main program to access R. Think of R as an engine and RStudio as a car dashboard‚ÄîR handles all the calculations and the actual statistics, while RStudio provides a nice interface for running R code. RStudio.cloud R is free, but it can sometimes be a pain to install and configure.

item.title: Reference
item.description: Contents Citations and bibliography Information Visualization & Visual Analytics Courses Interesting and excellent real world examples How to select the appropriate chart type Helpful data visualization resources Visualization in Excel Visualization in Tableau Working with R and ggplot2 R in the wild Data Pulling your own data: Past datasets: Colors Fonts Markdown Citations and bibliography ⊕You can open the file in BibDesk on macOS, JabRef on Windows, or Zotero or Mendeley online.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: Here‚Äôs your roadmap for the semester! Readings should be completed before each class session Assignments are due by 11:59 PM on the day they are due Class materials (slides, in-class activities, etc.) will be added on the day of class Information Visualization Reading Assignment Class August 19 Class 1: Intro to Visual Analytics August 19 Datacamp course 1 (Due Sept 3) August 26 Class 2: Visual Representations I August 26 Problem set 1 (Due Sept 16) September 2 No class (Labor Day) September 9 Class 3: Visual Representations II September 9 Quiz 1 (Due Sept 16) September 9 Datacamp course 2 (Due Sept 24) September 16 Class 4: Time & Space September 16 Problem set 2 (Due Oct 7) September 23 Class 5: Distributions & Uncertainty Interactive Visualizations Reading Assignment Class September 30 Class 6: Statistical Models September 30 Design Contest assigned (Due Oct 28) October 7 No class (Fall Break) October 14 Class 7: Multidimensional Data October 14 Quiz 2 (Due Oct 21) October 14 Datacamp course 3 (Due Nov 5) October 21 Class 8: Networks and Trees October 28 Class 9: Design Contest Presentations Building Shiny Apps Reading Assignment Class November 4 Class 10: Intro to Shiny November 4 Problem set 3 (Due Nov 18) November 4 Final project assigned (Due Dec 9) November 11 Class 11: Reactive Programming November 11 Datacamp course 4 (Due Nov 26) November 11 Quiz 3 (Due Nov 18) November 18 Class 12: Interactions & Frameworks November 18 Problem set 4 (Due Dec 2) November 25 Class 13: Shiny in Production November 25 Quiz 4 (Due Dec 2) December 2 Class 14: Python Final Reading Assignment Class December 9 Final project due

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: Data rarely speaks for itself.⊕Instructor Ryan Wesslen CenterCity rwesslen@uncc.edu @ryanwesslen Office Hours via Calendly Course Mondays August 19 ‚Äì Dec. 9, 2019 6:00‚Äì8:45 PM CenterCity 904 Slack By itself, the facts contained in raw data are difficult to understand, and in the absence of beauty and order, it is impossible to understand the truth that the data shows. In this class, you‚Äôll learn how to use industry-standard graphic and data design techniques to create beautiful, understandable visualizations and uncover truth in data.
